title: Wednesday, 26th September 2018
bodyHTML:
11:10 am
BE11:10am

Yes, hi, sorry. We're here.

Blank canvas good morning everyone
Soundbuy Morning
VV75 morning
BE11:10am

I was stuck on other things this morning, hence the delayed start.

jaws g m
A. M. Morning all.'The pessimist' was good.
BE11:11am

Not that there's a whole lot do do this morning. If you can find a market wrap that doesn't say something along the lines of "awaiting the Fed" in the first par, well done.

hedgehog AA?
A. M. Any blurb on Total?
11:13 am
BE11:13am

Should we get FOMC out of the way first? I mean, it's not until 7pm and the market's fully priced in 25 bips so it's not that interesting, but ......

BE11:14am

Kit Jukes of SocGen will do for context.

BE11:14am

The Fed’s ‘dot-plot’ currently shows a projected median long-term (i.e., neutral) Funds rate of 2.9%, but an overshoot to 3.1% in 2019 and 3.4% in 2020. I can’t think of any reason to push those higher, but that won’t prevent more FOMC members stressing the difference between ‘neutral’ and ‘peak’ rates. Our US economics team look for the introduction of a 2021 dot to see a 3.6y% projection, which would reinforce the idea that as long as the economy is growing above trend, the FOMC may need to take rates further into ‘tight’ territory

11:14 am
BE11:14am

The idea of rates peaking above the 2.9% neutral level isn’t shocking, even if the forward rate curve still undershoots the median dot path. With US economic data consistently strong, and with wage growth on a clear, if slow, rising trend, there’s enough to keep upward pressure on Treasury yields. But how does that affect the dollar? The FX market ought to go on focusing on the destination of Fed policy rather than the shorter-term path, and of course, on relative rates rather than just what happens in the US. At 3.14% today, US 1-year rates 5 years forwards are above the long-term dot, but below the May peak, and better described as being at the top end of their current range than anything else. Real long-term rate spreads between Euros and dollars are going sideways (as both rise together), and EUR/USD is mostly driven by positions. Those provide some euro support, as indeed do GBP positions for sterling

BE11:15am

Dot plot analysis.

BE11:16am

We're waiting nearly half a day to see some dots. It must be difficult to explain what we do to people of a non-financial bent and convince them we're not pulling their chain.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Here's Davy.

BE11:16am

In June, the dot plot indicated that eight members of the FOMC expected rates to rise to 2.25-2.5% by end-2018, with seven below. However, since June, labour market data have beaten expectations and more dovish FOMC members such as Charles Evans and Lael Brainard have made more hawkish comments. So the 77% implied probability of a fourth rate hike in December may well rise today.

undefined
Stateless @BE and by "We're" you mean the entire global financial working population today, basically

BE11:18am

And to AA, which is the only UK news of consequence on the tape this morning.

AA PLC (AA.:LSE): Last: 106.60, down 12.9 (-10.79%), High: 119.00, Low: 104.90, Volume: 3.23m

Playing FTSE AA damaged by potholes

The numbers are much as AA said they'd be in August.

11:19 am

Membership numbers look slightly light but profit is in line and guidance is unchanged.

BE11:20am

EBITDA of £161m, meaning a margin hit of !7.4 percentage points! at 33.5%

BE11:20am

So ... why are they down 12% live?

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Well, for that you have to look at the net debt to EBITDA of 7.4 times .......

BE11:21am

And the simple fact that, while numbers were in line, AA has to do better in the second half to meet guidance.

Soundbuy Lumbered with debt and yet paying a divy..........
wayneJ If I recall correctly the AA also has a large Capex cycle currently - the result of ‘PE’ style underinvestment
BE11:23am

Without an obvious route to raise cash if needed, because of the weird securitisation structure. Which makes it a prisoner of .... well, weather, mostly.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

Here's Citi.

BE11:23am

Roadside (82% of EBITDA) — Revenues were up +2.2% YoY to £411m helped by additional pay-for-use B2B sales on 8% higher breakdowns, and to a small extent by consolidation of AA Cars. EBITDA margin declined 750bps to 32.1% on higher garaging costs and strategic investment into 65 new patrols and more than the originally planned 200 call centre staff. Paid B2C members were down -2% and B2B members were down -3%. Average income per B2C member was up 2% at £159 and up 5% to £21 for B2B members. The group has successfully renegotiated several major B2B contracts, however no update was provided regarding the large Lloyds TSB contract. More than 1m members are now registered for the AA App and is being used in 34% of breakdowns (28% 1H18). c15,500 Car Genie units were activated by AA members at the end of August 2018.

BE11:23am

Insurance (18% of EBITDA) — Revenues were flat at £69m as underwriting
revenues grew to £8m from £3m in 1H18, helping offset the impact of lower revenues from Home Emergency services business which was sold in January 2018. EBITDA margin declined 710bps to 42.0% on a higher mix of the lower margin underwriting business and increased marketing spend. The motor policy book had 7% growth to 659k and home policy book has stabilized at 816k.

Pharma I'm not a professional investor, but I do struggle to understand why *anyone* would think buying a company from PE would be a good idea.
Excel Developer @Soundbuy: that's what debt is for, take on debt to lower WACC (assumes cost of debt is lower than cost of equity) to supercharge returns to equity holders.
wayneJ PE investors have never met a company whose returns can not be improved by adding more debt
11:24 am
BE11:24am

Or more pointedly, Jefferies .....

BE11:24am

interim EPS of 6.5p implies 55% needed in 2H (vs 52% usually).

Tom Dalgleish @Pharma occasionally it can be a good idea
wayneJ @excel - and the tax shield on interest pyments
Viking1 Mackenzie legacy issues?
Pharma @WayneJ - you forgot to add "in the short term"
Excel Developer @wayej: sure, thanks.
BE11:25am

Which I think Barclays disagrees with ......

11:24 am
BE11:25am

The 1H results reiterate FY19 EBITDA guidance (£335-345m) and medium term targets. Trading EBITDA of £161m in 1H would imply a 47.5%/52.5% profit split for the full year, which is consistent with prior years, in our view, and a reasonable result given breakdowns are up 8% yoy in 1H due to the weather. Adjusted EPS of 6.5p is in line with our expectations.

BE11:25am

We have an EW rating, as we see material share price upside being contingent on management executing on market expectations in FY21/CY20e, which we are unlikely to have increased visibility of for quite some time, in our view.

BE11:26am

So .... why down 12% on results that don't tell us that much new?

hedgehog Liberum cut AA estimates
Grouchmonkey Morning
Pharma @Tom, OK, I'll bite... what occasions?
Tom Dalgleish Like 25X in 12 years ex PE would have to be good non?
TheDubliner Sound advice from the FT - I'm off to the pub... https://www.ft.com/video/d633c443-339b-448a-b321-b075d9798d18?playlist-name=latest&playlist-offset=2
11:26 am
BE11:27am

I reiterate: net debt to EBITDA of 7.4 times. The equity's nearly irrelevant.

Tom Dalgleish http://bigcharts.marketwatch.com/quickchart/quickchart.asp?symb=AU:JBH&insttype=Stock&freq=2&show=&time=20
wayneJ @pharma - indeed - for the duration of the explicit forecast period which often coincides with the fund holding period and then bringing the debt down is someone else’s problem
BE11:27am

The Liberum forecast cut referred to on the right, BTW, is just stale numbers adjusting to consensus.

BE11:27am

We reduce our 2020 FD EPS by 17% to 15.5p to be more in line with the median consensus of 14.7p. Our FY 2019 net debt nudged down from £2,710m to £2,694m. At Roadside, we increase the FY 2019 Paid Membership decline from 1% to 2%. We remain optimistic about future Roadside Paid Membership growth. At B2B ARPU growth more than off-set the expected customer decline, and we await news on Lloyds in H2. At Insurance Services, EBITDA fell due to investment but strong growth at the in-house insurer and Motor book. Credit markets are challenging which reduces the probability of a re-fi of the B2s next year. Attractive CY 2019 free cash flow for equity yield of 13.2%, but TP from 140p to 130p to reflect 2020.

Grouchmonkey @A.M. re the Shetland gas find? I am interested as to why that has had zero effect on the price of SSE, which has a minority stake in the block.
11:28 am
BE11:28am

They also chuck in this rather hopeful par.

BE11:28am

At the FY results, the company mentioned that it had taken part in routine conversations with PE firms but that no substantive approach had been made. An early indicative approach by Hellman & Friedman last year was leaked to the press by Bob Mackenzie in relation to his claim. We believe that PE would be more comfortable with The AA’s leverage, although rising debt yields may make the equities less attractive. Any bid would clearly have to be at a significant premium to the equity. A private equity bid for the RAC could also provide an interesting reference point for the AA’s valuation, as it has done in the past.

wayneJ Vs Activists - who push for listed companies to sell off their profitable businesses and then lever up and pay special dividends - enhancing returns during their holding periods
BE11:29am

Yeah, maybe.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Morgan Stanley can summarise for us.

BE11:32am

Boohoo beat on the top line and EBITDA, with revenue growth
of +50% (consensus +46%) and Adj EBITDA margin of 10% (vs
consensus 9.8%). The company has raised FY guidance to 38-
43% (from 35-40%, consensus +42%)

BE11:32am

On a segmental basis … Boohoo reported revenue of £209m (+15%), in line with our estimates and consensus of £209m (+15%). This implies a reacceleration to 17% growth in Q2 (from +12% in 1Q), albeit on 10%pt easier comp. Pretty Little Thing generated £168.6m (+132%), ahead of both MSe of £156m (+115%) and consensus of £155m (+113%). The gross margin improved 250bps to 57.3%, which is reassuring given the warehouse transition during the period. At Nasty Gal revenue was +111% to £17.7m, ahead of our estimate of £17m (+107%) but behind consensus of £19m (+128%).

Pharma @Tom, perhaps your examples show that Australian PE firms are just letting the side down.
A. M. (@wayneJ/PE : nicely put)
Tom Dalgleish @Pharma, some are

Excel Developer @soundbuy: good one!
A. M. @Grouchmonkey: also Total's approach to the NS compared to, say, Chevron.
11:33 am
BE11:34am

Main point here is that guidance only moves up to where the sellside consensus was, but that's apparently enough.

cracklenpop @waynej It's what the Glazers did when they bought debt-free Man Utd....
BE11:34am

The company has raised full-year guidance from 35- 40% to 38-43% and adj. EBITDA margins of 9-10% are unchanged. With consensus already at +42% to £826m, we could see some minor upward revisions to top-line estimates. However, raising top-line guidance and maintaining Adj. EBITDA margin following the warehouse transition, which has been a source of uncertainty, will likely be taken as a positive, we believe.

BE11:34am

Valuation too, since we're here.

11:34 am

....trading on 2.1x 2019e EV/Sales, c.22x EV/EBITDA and c.41x P/E vs. ASOS on 1.5x / 21.6x /c.49x and Zalando on 1.2x 23.6x 67x.

Excel Developer I don't scrape info from this room but did write a personal comments zapper.
A. M. I'm obviously a misinformed layperson, but whenever I read about some PE shenanigan involving extra debt/fees/etc., I'm thinking of that bit from Goodfellas.
nightingale20201 not cheap...any concerns with CAPEX.. it seems that the mgt is pretty confident in the CAPEX guidance even with the PLT's transition
BE11:36am

.... 41x might look a bit poppy for a business where questions have been asked about related party transactions and so on .... but, whatever. Here's Peel Hunt buying.

Blue horseshoe... Fever tree any thoughts?
BE11:36am

Guidance for revenue growth has increased from a range of 35-40% revenue growth to 38-43%, still lagging our 47.4% growth rate. The EBITDA margin is still guided to 9-10%. This creates a guided EBITDA range of £72-83m compared to PHe of £81.1m and consensus of £78m. We see scope for modest upgrades to EBITDA forecasts for consensus and also potential for our own PBT estimate to rise (our full year depreciation estimate of £13m looks high against H1 charge of £4.3m). Either way, boohoo looks in an incredibly confident position ahead of peak; full price sales have outperformed over H1 and the group is carrying significant firepower into Black Friday and peak trading; January trading upgrades look likely. Trading on 2.4x sales, we reiterate our BUY stance.

wayneJ @excel - I am pretty dumb; but I would suggest the U.K. in particular has also suffered from interest streaming to Jersey etc which previous Govts have tried to clamp down on. Re impact of clamping on PE style structures - I believe govts have looked at this - I think there probably ought to be a limit. I think a lot of PE buying currently is arbitrage of leverage between public and private markets - and I think rising interest rates could be a painful moment for investors in PE funds independent of any leverage limits
11:37 am

11:45 am

Here's RBC.

Imperial Goldsmith Performance of football team largely irrelevant w/ media/sponsorship rights main selling point
wayneJ @excel - that is an interesting point - am bemused that retail home owners are allowed higher leverage on an illiquid asset with high entry / exit fees than professional investors are in listed equities
BE11:45am

The shares have done very little of late and this remain one of the cheaper stocks in our coverage universe on a CY19E PE of c10x and EV/EBITA of c9x. Whilst its end markets remain challenging from a volume and pricing perspective, its cost saving initiatives should ensure that margins remain underpinned – we would note that we only forecast margins of 3.7% over our forecast horizon (compared to its medium-term aspirations of 4.5%-5.5%). Technology is clearly seen as a big differentiator (and a likely source of margin enhancement) and we also like the fact that management is improving the ‘credibility’ of the balance sheet. This will be a slow burn, but it is encouraging to see guidance held and with the rating not prohibitive for a turnaround we retain our positive stance.

BE11:46am

And Jefferies.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

1) guidance for FY19E EBITA (consensus £98-99m) and project Helix costs/benefits are unchanged; 2) profit progress will be H2 weighted this year with H1 “flat to slightly down” before cost efficiencies benefit the second half; 3) billing cycle improvements have been delayed while some finance activities are offshored to India and consequently the balance sheet is not improving: average net debt will be £40m higher YOY in H1 and FY19E net debt will be flat at c£193m (JEFe £160m); 4) organic revenue growth is expected to be 2-3% in H119E.

Excel Developer @waynej: well the leverage in equities is baked in already as per previous discussion. I don;t have to borrow money for shares to lever up because the CFO has already issued corporate debt. IMHO.
cracklenpop @wayneJ Why try to predict future performance when you can just buy trophies if you spend enough: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2018-09-25/has-anyone-seen-roman-abramovich-the-last-days-of-londongrad

wayneJ @excel - seriously I think it will be hard to put the leverage genie back in the box as it is likely to be possible to bypass govt leverage limits - but I think PE investors will gradually become more sophisticated - but interesting that some large US state based investors have even had difficulty working out what returns they have had from private rquity

.......... you can guess much of this already. Cashflow sucks, exceptionals constant, JVs troublesome, revenue somewhat difficult to connect to billings.

Excel Developer @waynej: ok, I agree lawyers will find loopholes and ways around any clampdown.
wayneJ And the ‘sharpe ratios’ some private equity funds give is based on them using a parameter where they never show any daily volatility in their unlisted investments and mark them upwards over time
A. M. @wayneJ: you'd think they'd know how much money went in and how much came back out..
BE11:48am

You'll remember Liberum knocking down these points one-by-one pre last week's numbers from Kier.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Today, though, we get JP Morgan Caz choosing its side. And it's chosen "not convinced".

BE11:49am

We are downgrading Kier to Neutral following the group's FY18 results.
Management has presented new FY21 period-end and average net debt
guidance (£0m and £250m), benefitting from the new Future Proofing Kier
programme. While we still like Kier's business mix, the group’s poor cash
flow track record somewhat reduces our confidence in management’s
medium-term guidance. We, hence, move to Neutral with a revised SOTP
Jun-19 1,042p PT, down from 1,369p reflecting our lower confidence in the
group’s medium-term cash flows.

wayneJ Can’t remember which one - but one of the Big US state or city . Funds seemed to have difficulty
BE11:50am

Seems the £32m of cash exceptional outflows in the FY update were what pushed it over the edge.

wayneJ Can’t pecisely remember whether it was lack of clarity on return or the fees they had paid or both
Viking1 WayneJ excellent point on the Private Equity NAVHence they never buy an investment bank
11:50 am
BE11:50am

Since FY13, Kier’s year-end net debt has increased by £246m, while average net debt has increased by £371m. This increase in
indebtedness is despite the average capital employed in Residential and
Property having remained essentially flat over the same period. The primary cause of this poor cash performance appears to have been c.£242m of cash exceptionals since FY13.

BE11:50am

So we get the laundry list.

BE11:50am

Kier’s valuation is clearly optically attractive, in our view, and we
expect a successful delivery of management’s guidance to be taken
positively by the market. However. given the company’s poor cash flow
track record and what we see as multiple possible "red flags" (such rising net debt, average vs year-end gap widening, reverse factoring, JV usage,
exceptionals etc), we prefer to be Neutral for now.

Tom Dalgleish @Wayne yes very excellent

wayneJ Throw in stuff like charging reporting formats (very few companies keep reports constant over ten years) and private equity becomes faith investing

Total was a strategy day yesterday, wasn't it? Doesn't seem to have done an awful for for the shares.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Just reading Exane on it .....

BE11:56am

This year’s Investor Day showcased consistency in strategy. A weaker immediate share price reaction reflected in part some ‘travel and arrive’ on the event and was in the context of some rather premature hopes for an increase in the existing buyback program. It didn’t reflect what we see as greater evidence for the building blocks for upstream value growth beyond 2022 which is led by the Deepwater and LNG, two core strategic themes for Total. We conclude for medium-term investors, our ‘Oily growth with Integration value’ thesis holds with c600kboe/d from start-ups (2018-2020) complementing what remains a resilient cashflow of cUSD7bn pa from the downstream. In terms of valuation, we maintain a free cash flow yield of c9% at USD70/bbl more than underpins a dividend commitment of 4.6%.

VV75 @Viking1 yeah but try buying in at those valuations..no chance.
Tom Dalgleish Galbraith did a great service to humanity with his description of the bezzle
wayneJ Yep - and in private equity / VC - the high return companies have a bell shaped Harvest period - either early on or very late - and the ‘gunk’ often sits in the portfolio for a long time - or is written down when the fund also does a big ‘headline’ deal or has good news
Viking1 Interesting that Daimler have pick a non German ( Swedish ) to take over .Last non German to run a large German company was the previous CEO of Deutsche BHmm

11:58 am
BE11:58am

The appointment of Mr. Andrea Orcel could be understood in many ways. What it is clear is that his profile and background (a well-recognized dealmaker, more geared to investment banking activities rather than pure
retail banking) may fuel speculations about the future strategy of Santander. In our opinion, his short term to-do list should be focused in two main areas: a better capital allocation within the subsidiaries and Santander’s profitability improvement.

BE11:59am

As part of an effort to transform UBS into a smaller, more profitable firm focused on wealth management and away from more risky trading activities in its investment bank, Mr. Orcel carried out some divestments that in the context of Santander could also have sense. Thus, we think that selling some banking operations (such as US retail bank or some small emerging market divisions) could be a meaningful catalyst, maintaining a presence in the USA through SCUSA and also improving the capital ratios of Santander.
